children: A 36-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is evaluated for fever and cough.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This frontal chest radiograph shows a lung abscess. Radiographic findings include a cavitary pulmonary infiltrate, partial central clearing, and an air-fluid level; these findings are consistent with a lung abscess. The most common cause of lung abscess is aspiration, most typically in patients that experienced an episode of decreased consciousness. These abscesses are the result of polymicrobial infection. Cavitary tuberculosis tends to be located in the apical segments of the upper and lower lobes and may be associated with hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.
